In the years between the World Wars, Agent BloodRayne works as a killing machine for The Brimstone Society--a top secret fraternity that hunts down and destroys supernatural threats. Starring heroine Rayne, this original action horror game unleashed the red headed dhampir on the world.

About This Game

In the years between the World Wars, Agent BloodRayne works as a killing machine for The Brimstone Society--a top secret fraternity that hunts down and destroys supernatural threats. Two missions, five years apart, turn out to be connected by one man. For years, this man has been searching the world for powerful occult relics to bring Germany into a new age of domination. Rayne must face his elite Nazi army and prevent them from releasing horrific creatures in their quest for the artifacts. Starring the super-sexy, super-lethal, supernatural heroine BloodRayne, this original action horror game unleashed the red headed dhampir on the world.
READ MORE

System Requirements

    Minimum: Windows 98/2000/XP, 733 MHz processor, 128MB RAM, 200MB virtual memory, 2 GB free hard disc space, DirectX 8.1 or higher (included with game), DirectX compatible sound card, 100% DirectX 8.1 compatible video card, ATI Radeon, GeForce 2 or higher, with Hardware T&L (Transform & Lighting). Excludes GeForce MX and Go series cards. See full list below.
    Excluded cards:
    - TnT/TnT 2
    - ATI Rage (any kind)
    - ATI Radeon VE and Radeon 7000
    - ATI Mobility Radeon (original, laptop)
    - Kyro 1 & 2 (example, Hercules 3D Prophet 4000/4500)
    - any Voodoo card
    - any Intel card
    - any Matrox card (except the Parhelia)
    - any kind of integrated graphics (except the nForce)

    Recommended: Windows XP, Pentium 4 2.53 GHz or AMD equivalent, 512 MB RAM, 200MB virtual memory, 2 GB free hard disc space, 64MB nVidia GeForce 3, GeForce 4 Ti or ATI Radeon 8500 video card, DirectX 8.1 or higher (included with game), Sound Blaster Audigy sound card

VlkStínu
177 products in account
2 reviews
Recommended
8.3 hrs on record
Posted: June 23
FOR WINDOWS 7/8 TIPS ON HOW TO RUN THE GAME SMOOTHLY AND WITHOUT ISSUES, SEE BELOW!

BloodRayne is truely a nostalgic classic for me and I have to say, I still enjoy this title even after 12 years of my initial first playthrough. It has many flaws, but above all these, it has a swift and amusing gameplay, great heroine constantly throwing out black humor quotes and the "cutting system" (you can literally cut any imaginable little piece of body, like a quarter of face or piece of fingers. Or you can slice and dice the bad guys like a bread into a thousand of segments - what a highly sophisticated technology for such an old game! :-D ) of enemies can be really strangely satisfying.

Sadly, as this is an old game, it has issues when you try to run it on newer versions of Windows, such as low resolution, crashes and also sound clipping during cutscenes. I did my research and manage to find an ultimate solution for every problem:

To solve crashes, go to your Steam directory Steam/steamapps/common/BloodRayne and in the folder, right click on rayne.exe and set it's compatibility mode to Windows 98/ME. Also, be sure to check you have disabled the DPI scaling (it is in the same tab as the compatibility setting). This solved all the crashes for me and I haven't got a single crash in 4 hour playthrough.

For low resolution solution, launch the Bloodrayne first and after entering the menu, starting a new game, go through the first cutscenes and then quit the game. After that, go to your Steam directory Steam/steamapps/common/BloodRayne/system and in the folder, open rayne.ini - In the .ini file, search for these two gamePIXY= gamePIXX= and after the "=", type your desired resolution (for example gamePIXY=1440 gamePIXX=2560). I run the game in 2560x1440 without any problem.

And finally, to solve the sound clipping issue, install MSI Afterburner. The clipping is caused by the fact that the game is designed to run on 30 FPS max and newer computers run it on higher FPS - that is causing the problem. So you have to lock/cap your FPS to 30. To do that, install MSI Afterburner and load it. Wait until a RivaTuner icon shows in your system tray and after that, right click on it, select Show and set your FPS limit in the interface to 30 FPS. Remember to always turn Afterburner on if you want to play BloodRayne.

Hope this will help to enjoy this great classic! Cheers!

Buttman
462 products in account
2 reviews
Recommended
19.8 hrs on record
Posted: August 29
Now, now, where to begin with?

To put it simply, this game is like a big budget cult B-movie, if that makes any sense!

I had played it back in the day in the first Xbox and I was unsure if I would still like it, however replaying it was quite a satisfying experience, so sit back and let me explain:


--- What is good about this game:

- It contains and blends many many elements from other successful games and does that quite well, namely it has elements from:

Max Payne: graphics and eternal night atmosphere are similar, there is a slow motion mode here as well, named Dilated Perception and even the game's name has the same pun (max payne/max pain, bloodrayne/blood rain). To top it all, there's also a level where you have to escape from fires & explosions, much like in a Max Payne level!

Return to Castle Wolfenstein (and the Raiders of the Lost Ark Indiana Jones movie): the game is filled with classic power hungry Nazis who seek supernatural relics, as well as zombies, vampires and other monsters, you couldn't ask for more! You can feel the rottenness in the air everywhere! (the spiders of the initial levels even reminded me of Dead Space's necromorphs at times)

Devil May Cry: similar gameplay, where you wield both a close range sword-like weapon (dual blades in this case) and a long range type weapon, namely pistols, rifles and rocket launchers!

You also get to jump quite high, which is great, since you avoid much platforming and feel like a true vampire. In fact, Rayne's single jump is of the same length, if not a bit greater, as Dante's double jump!

- The atmosphere and music are quite good, despite their age, you have your classic zombie/vampire/third reich horror setting, where the dawn of the day is almost nonexistent. However, since it's an action game and Rayne is quite unstoppable, it's not as scary as, say, the Resident Evil or Dead Space games, where your movements are more confined (though there is a level where a horde of worm-like zombies chase you and you are weaponless and can only run, that was quite a tense and scary moment).

- The heroine of the game, Rayne, is a really hot and kickass redhead, pretty much the female half-vampire equivalent of Blade and she kills/dismembers every enemy with quite some style and as a matter of fact she also swears a lot! You'll hear the F-word and B-words (both male and female one) quite some times and towards the end she even shows the middle finger! Not even the God of War games, despite their gore and violence, have so much swearing! She also, like Max Payne, speaks many witty and cheesy lines!

Sucking Blood from various enemies is quite cool as well and as is the Blood Rage mode, which is your typical limited time Berserker/God mode, where you are almost invincible for a short period of time... and dismember every poor enemy in your way!

In a particular level you even get to drive a Mech suit, felt really cool too!

- The old fashioned cheats system the game enables you to input, where among them existed a cheat that enlarged the female characters' breasts (!) and another that showed how the main character would look like if all the weapons she carried were on her body! There's even a hidden thank you message cheat!

- Violence, decapitations, dismemberments, swearing, buckets of blood sprayed everywhere... oh, did I mention violence?


--- What is bad about this game:

- It feels too much like a true B-movie (or B-game, if you want) at times and the graphics are quite dated for our day.

- The gameplay is a bit restricted and you pretty much end up doing the same and the same after a certain point, but I cannot totally blame it, since even Max Payne (or other great 3rd person games) had quite a bit of repetitiveness, but I never saw anyone complain!

The slowmotion ability is not as good as Max Payne's however, as it's infinite and it doesn't really add superspeed to your movements, alas just the ability to see everything slower and move accordingly at your pace, but it gets too slow and boring to use most of the time.

The game's blades are also limited in their attacks (unlike the long range weapons which have some variety at least) and end up quite boring too to use (except from a stealth fatality attack which dismembers unaware enemies from behind and is quite cool, but rare).

- While Rayne is almost unstoppable (a lot thanks to being able to blood-suck dry almost any enemy, except bosses of course), in the limited occasions where you lose you have to start the whole level from the beginning, as there are no checkpoints or a free save system. That made the game quite frustrating.

- The initial swamp levels are a bit misleading about the game's entertainment factor, as I've heard of people dropping the game because of them. Just have some patience, when the Nazis enter the scene, the fun begins!


All in all, that said, I wholeheartedly recommend the game for cult B-movie lovers: it's dated, cheesy and filled with swearing and gratouitous violence, what's not to like??!

Posted: October 20
First things first, BloodRayne isn't a bad game and its far from that. I don't recommend it to anyone if you're playing on a newer operative system. The game will crash, the game will glitch, the game will run "too fast", the voice will get cut. I got tired of messing with the game files and ended buying the GOG version and problem solved. I don't know why the game hasn't been optimised on Steam too. Such a shame.

In the current state of this game (on Steam) I can't recommend it.

pawlak.bartlomiej
146 products in account
1 review
Recommended
1.7 hrs on record
Posted: August 9
Overall I've played the game a while ago and made it till the end.

Technical stuff.
The game engine is a little heavy if You run the game in DX mode on an IntelHD card.
I'm not able to run the game on the dedicated GTX860M card in DX/OpenGL on Win8.1
The game itself was made for consoles (as I remember PS2) but it plays quite nice with kb/mouse.
If You use additional software like Pinnacle Profiler, then it's also playable with X360 and XOne controller.
Unfortunatelly, setting the gamepad without a profiler is a mess, but it can be done if You are using a DirectInput device.
Xinput devices may have axis recognision problems.
So, with a little tinkering, it's playable (FHD resolution) on an intel i5-4210H with intelHD graphics, Windows 8.1, without compatibility settings (tested with 16GB RAM but it shouldn't make any difference).
The engine graphics are PS2 level with the option to set it to a high resolution. You can edit the ini file if You want a custom resolution.

Game
Very playable, TPP, specially if You like shooting Nazi's + Vampire motives.
You can bite foes and suck the blood out of them to replenish Your health.
Melee is a little bit anoying (targeting system) but looks fun when You activate Blood Rage mode.
Story is also acceptable. After finishing the game, You will probably want to know what happened later - Me too.
So when I'm thru with part one once again (it's more than 10 years that I've played it) I'll gladly head for part 2 because I didn't had the opportunity to play it back then.
It's an "old fashion" game so don't expect to unlock anything after ending the game, except some Steam cards maybe.

I recommend the game if You like slashing, gore, vampires and a lot of blood.
